Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Exploring the 60 GHz Spectral Frontier for Multi-Gigabit Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The exponential growth of wireless data traffic causes spectrum depletion and significantly stresses the capacity of existing and future wireless networks. The massive unlicensed bandwidth in the 60 GHz band provides great potential to meet the surging wireless data demand. The goal of this project is to gain a deep understanding of the 60 GHz propagation and channel characteristics, and to develop effective 60 GHz network protocols. This project falls into four interacted thrusts: (i) 60 GHz 3-D channel propagation measurement and modeling; (ii) MAC scheduling in 60 GHz networks; (iii) 60 GHz mesh network protocols; and (iv) enabling rich multimedia communications in 60 GHz networks. Various methods including field testing and measurements, mathematical modeling, network protocol design, distributed control, and cross-layer optimization are adopted to address the research challenges.

This project is part of a broad and ambitious global effort to develop novel techniques to exploit the huge license-free spectrum in the 60 GHz band in face of the exponential wireless data growth. It has the potential to accelerate the deployment of more powerful, bandwidth intensive, ubiquitous and cheaper wireless applications and services, and the support of more versatile, robust and rich-multimedia wireless networks. Complementary to the research agenda, the project also carries out a broad range of education and outreach activities, including integration of research findings into wireless engineering courses, textbook development, promoting underrepresented and undergraduate populations, collaboration with an HBCU, and participating in existing programs at the PIs' institutions for outreach to K-12 students and teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The exponential growth of wireless data traffic causes spectrum depletion and will significantly stress the capacity of existing and future wireless networks. The unlicensed spectrum at the 60 GHz band, with up to 7 GHz bandwidth available in most part of the world, is at the spectral frontier where high-bandwidth commercial wireless communication systems will use, for the first time, highly directional antennas and new medium access control protocols. This massive unlicensed bandwidth provides great potential to meet the surging wireless data demand. 

The unique characteristics of 60 GHz channels create many technical issues that are significantly different from conventional wireless networks and raise substantial technical challenges. The highly directional links in 60 GHz systems, necessary to counter the severe attenuation, entail a complete rethinking of wireless network protocol design. This is like a double-edged sword: On one hand, carrier sensing and node coordination are very hard due to the inherent deafness problem; On the other hand, the highly directional transmissions greatly reduce interference and allow a high level of spatial reuse, thus providing great potential to enhance network capacity. 

Intellectual Merit: In light of the vast license-free spectrum in the 60 GHz band, the goal of this project is to gain a deep understanding of the 60 GHz propagation and channel characteristics and to develop effective 60 GHz network protocols. The team has developed the theory and algorithms to significantly improve the capacity and transmission reliability with concurrent and intelligent exploration of spatial reuse, spatial multiplexing, effective frame-based scheduling and relay. Effective techniques have also been developed to support rich multimedia applications in millimeter wave networks. In particular, the following studies have been completed. The NYU team of this collaborative project has investigated the problem of 60 GHz 3-D channel propagation measurement and modeling. The Auburn team of this project has developed effective networking algorithms for (i) link scheduling in 60 GHz networks; (ii) 60 GHz mesh/ad hoc network protocols; and (iii) enabling rich multimedia communications in 60 GHz networks. Various methods including field testing and measurements, mathematical modeling, network protocol design, distributed control, and cross-layer optimization have been adopted to address the research challenges. 

Broader Impacts: This project is part of a broad and ambitious global effort to develop novel techniques to exploit the huge license-free spectrum in the 60 GHz band in face of the exponential wireless data growth. The outcomes from this project has accelerated the deployment of more powerful, bandwidth intensive, ubiquitous and cheaper wireless applications and services, and the support of more versatile, robust and rich-multimedia wireless networks. Complementary to the research agenda, the project also carried out a broad range of education and outreach activities, including integration of research findings into wireless engineering courses, textbook development, promoting underrepresented and undergraduate populations, collaboration with HBCUs, and participating in the existing programs at the PIs' institutions for outreach to K-12 students and teachers.
